subsection_content_1: A study by researchers in Nebraska shows that avian influenza virus from poultry carcasses remains infectious in landfill leachate for at least 30 days and up to 600 days, which is almost two years. The study showed that elevated temperature and acidic or alkaline pH can reduce the survival time of the virus in landfills. The researchers concluded that landfills are an appropriate place to dispose of carcasses infected with bird flu because they are designed to hold material for much longer than two years.
subsection_content_4:
Egypt. A four-year-old boy and a four-year-old girl from the Sharqeya governate in the Nile Delta were confirmed of contracting H5N1 bird flu on May 27. The girl fell ill on May 23 and the boy fell ill the next day both have been hospitalized and are in stable condition after being treated with Tamiflu. There have now been 76 human cases of bird flu in Egypt since the disease first appeared.
            (
subsection_content_3: Índia. In the Uttar Dinajpur district of West Bengal twenty rural backyard poultry died in an outbreak that began on May 20. All domestic poultry in a 3km radius have been culled and the owners have been compensated. Within a 10km radius all poultry markets have been closed and premises have been disinfected.
subsection_content_2: Mongolia. An outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in migratory whooper swans has been reported in the Ugii-nuur soum (district) of Arkhangai. Nine of the swans died and one was culled as a result of the outbreak that began on May 22.
